instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message:
I GET 5.10V WITH 0.27A FOR 7 SECONDS THEN IT CYCLES AGAIN 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.23V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.20V 
Could <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> be bad

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message: Test if is recognized in DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message:
Any history available?
Both ports have the same behavior?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message: yes it shows 5v for 7 seconds then turns off and back on over and over

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message:
Check and compare diode mode readings (with good board) on all big coils.
Test what happens with known good battery (holding some charge).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message:
i put a working board in to check battery and keyboard all good i charge the battery
when i put back bad board it works from battery but the tpe c closes to screen only says 5v and the other one 
no voltage when i take off battery it goes back to five volts is <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> bad

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message: the big coils on both board are the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V ON AND OFF
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200.
Pay atention to CC1/2 lines.

Changing <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is a good option; is that is the affected channel.
